newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania needs action to prop up economy - analysts.
newsitem.headline: Romania needs action to prop up economy - analysts.

text.p: Romania's tough economic stabilisation programme could be successful provided loans worth $1.0 billion from international lenders are put to good use and the government matches words with deeds, analysts said.
Prime Minister Victor Ciorbea unveiled on Monday a package of radical reforms, promising only "work, sweat and austerity" to put Romanian economy on a market footing.
"It's a very good sign and (the reform package) it's much tougher than we believed," Andrew Kenningham, senior analyst at Merrill Lynch, said from London.
The government pledged to bring bulging deficits and inflation under control and to bring back economic growth next year after a forecasted 2.0 percent fall in 1997.

"This (programme) is a sacrifice requested from people who already own very little. But it's not possible to drag Romania's economy out of its present situation without it," local independent analyst Ilie Serbanescu said.
Romania is struggling with a surging inflation, which hit an year-on-year 56.9 percent in 1996, when its budget deficit widened to 5.7 percent of gross domestic product.
Inflation is forecast to soar to 97.0 percent this year, led by liberalisation of fuel, electricity and food prices.
The government's plan, drafted with International Monetary Fund and World Bank experts, includes liberalisation of the foreign exchange market, faster privatisation and restructuring.
Analysts said fast action to implement reforms and proper channelling of loans were vital to make the package successful.
"We have to judge by actions not by words. However, the programme looks very good," Merrill's Kenningham said.
"This programme is feasible only if the funds drawn from international lenders are properly used," a local banker said.
The IMF and World Bank withheld loans in 1996 on grounds that the former ruling leftists had stalled reforms.
IMF mission chief Poul Thomsen hailed Ciorbea's programme as "tough and ambitious" and said he was confident the new government would go on with reforms.

"Our experience with Romania in the past is that again and again stabilisation plans have broken down," Thomsen said in reference to previous Fund accords which failed during the former leftist government ousted in elections last November.
Reforms of the farming and energy-intensive sectors were crucial to stabilise the economy and secure loans, he said.
The government also promised social protection steps to cushion the impact of the painful reforms, expected to push unemployment rate to 8.0 percent, up from a current 6.7.
"The main problem is whether Romanians accept or not such a sacrifice," said Serbanescu.
